The air should be delivered to the cylinder through the hoses. The air should be delivered to the inlet side, not the exhaust side. The air is delivered to the cylinder in more than half the stroke. It is important to understand how to deal with pressure and vacuum to the piston of the cylinder during the stroke. The cylinder is a sealed container that has two valves that allow for an airflow through it. It has an inlet and an exhaust valve. When air is introduced, the air gets compressed to some pressure and a vacuum is created in the cylinder. The vacuum is then vented out through the exhaust valve. Evil spirits have different names: ghosts, monsters, demons, etc. Demonic possession has been with us since early humanity. In fact, ghosts and demons have been around since the time of the ancient Greeks and Egyptians. In fact, the early Greek myths recorded ghost stories and were full of descriptions of the fearful creatures that haunted the night. instruction: Girl I feel you on those scares! Can’t wait to also get my tubes tied so I can live out the days before my period without anxiety :(

LL on the body! I still have issues even after my surgery.
Sarah - Bays Honda March 27, 2016 at 5:38 AM
I was wondering if you do this without the use of a pillow? Just thought that could make a world of difference. Maybe you don't have to wake up. My sister had the procedure done and was not able to use the pillow or her arm.
Great information! Have you had any side affects so far? I am still looking into options because of the risks of having a second c-sec, I'm just a little nervous because it's so drastic.
Great explanation! I had mine almost three years ago and I wish I'd read about this first. I wish I'd known that after tubal ligation you would be able to have intercourse without a condom. Now I'm paying more in health insurance, I hope to have a few babies, and I want to use a condom. But my tubes are tied and I can't use a condom. I would give anything to have my tubes tied back open and try to conceive.
Great overview. I actually had mine done after my birth in labor and I still consider it a gift of the Lord. I had 6 miscarriages prior to my daughter as my body was not prepared to carry a healthy pregnancy. After my daughter, I had a c-section so I did all three. I would have done the tubes first as well if I had known. If I had to do it over, I would take that exact same procedure route.
Rachel Hollis March 27, 2016 at 6:45 PM

Dawn McAlexander March 28, 2016 at 9:19 AM
This is a wonderful post and it will certainly open up so many other eyes! I hope that even more women considering all of the options will find out about tubal ligation!
Gabriel March 28, 2016 at 9:21 AM
It was my wife who wanted tubal ligation. I had no problem. My wife doesn't like periods, so I understand. :-)
Alli March 28, 2016 at 9:22 AM
Great post- I am glad you were honest about what happened and your feelings! I was recently asked if I was considering having my tubes tied after one but since I don't plan on having anymore I said no!
I'm in the middle of my TA now. Had my right side done Feb. 2 with almost no problems. My first week of my menstrual cycle was more painful than the TA itself, but after that the pain was minimal. The best thing is I don't have to use birth control, and that makes me so grateful.
I also had an epidural for my son, but I don't remember it not working like the lady said- when I went into labor I gave birth with no pain. It sucked, but it had no impact on how I felt during the TA. I also had a little pain in my shoulder but took that up with the anesthesiologist and he was able to fix it with another shot. The only post op pain I have are small sores on my side where they had to get through one of the arteries- pretty normal stuff with any surgery, but the doctor assured me that those shouldn't be painful at all.
I'm a few years out from my surgery so I didn't give any stats right off the bat, but I will say that the surgery itself and recovery took less than a day. I was on crutches for about 8 hours, and the next day I was walking around without pain. It has been 2 weeks post op and I am still taking Motrin for occasional pain but I am mostly back to normal.
Thank you for sharing this information, I know it is difficult to be honest when writing about things like this because it has nothing to do with weight loss and we are so used to having the "skinny" talk in this community. But like I said, I am so thankful for the information and I really appreciate that you included such honest stats about your experience. Thank you!
Mattie @ Northwest Native March 28, 2016 at 10:26 AM
Thanks so much for sharing your experience, Liz! Sounds like you had a similar experience to mine, but I'm glad you were comfortable enough with your anesthesiologist to give him feedback on what you were feeling. I really appreciate that you left a comment here on my blog as well. :)
Ashley @ The Wandering Weekenders March 28, 2016 at 10:57 AM
These are all really good questions, and that's so great that you wrote this post to answer them for all of us! I definitely had some questions regarding the pros/cons and how long it would potentially take me to get pregnant again. I ended up getting my tubes tied and I'm so happy with the decision! It was something that I didn't even really have a strong opinion one way or another for, but after having 2 back to back miscarriages, I didn't want to be at risk of having to go through that again.
This was extremely informative, thank you so much for sharing! I was wondering how long it takes to get pregnant after a TA?
This is so informative! Thank you for posting this, I honestly didn't know if I wanted kids (and still don't for sure) but this clarified a lot and I feel like I understand way better now!
Meg Taylor March 28, 2016 at 5:19 PM
i really appreciate that you covered the 'not so positive' things with the tubal ligation. i have a few friends that are considering it so this is super informative!
I am pregnant, so this information isn't as helpful to me anymore. But I'm definitely going to bookmark this for future reference! Thank you so much for putting the stats in here!
You make such valid points about the tubes. People aren't just thinking about that side effect of not having another child, but also the potential risks it could have on a woman. The side I love is women saying, "If you are done, make this decision for yourself. If you aren't sure, talk to your Ob/Gyn and see how to proceed." I do think this is a great solution though.
Kelly @ A Girl Worth Saving March 29, 2016 at 12:30 AM
I am so thankful for this post. I had a TA a little over 10 months ago. We ended up deciding on that after my c-sections. I honestly have no regrets. I had a 19 month old son, 2 miscarriages, and 3 pregnancies total. The risks of me not wanting to have more children, the surgery itself, the 6 weeks without intercourse, and the risks of another c-section were all in line with the decision. The thing I struggled with the most after the surgery was the 6 week no intercourse rule. It was so hard for me to get myself to start having intercourse again. Luckily he was out of town for that six weeks which made it a bit easier. I was so scared I would "screw up the procedure" or "start having babies, even if only 1." Now I get to wait 6 weeks with him here since he is home for the summer! It's my first time in 5 years not in a relationship that we can have sex whenever we want. I love it! I have no symptoms at all. My menstruation has gotten a little lighter (more in tune with when I ovulate) and even stopped getting cramps for a while. We are still working hard on getting pregnant again for our 3rd. He was born in our first trimester due to a miscarriage, born early (due to a bleed for a cervical laceration) and is born 3 months too soon on the dot. We really want to give it a second try and see if we can have a healthy pregnancy, birth, and stay full term. I think the risk being pregnant would take is out weighed by the risk of a c-section or having another miscarriage. It was hard to tell a good friend I was pregnant this far along again and have to go through another miscarriage so we decided to get it fixed first. Even though my first miscarriage happened after our tubal ligation, I think for any women who has had or is having problems becoming pregnant, I recommend getting it done with some confidence in your mind already. I love you and love your honesty. You are so brave! Thank you for giving this post. Tough stuff!!!
Susannah March 29, 2016 at 9:10 AM
Oh, goodness, your experience is very similar to mine (although I had four miscarriages and was TA'd after two c-sections, not three)! It sounds like we have much in common. Hang in there, Kelly...the risk of miscarriage can be reduced through dietary changes, eating more of a high-quality meat intake, as well as supplementation. Good luck to you! xo
Kelly @ A Girl Worth Saving March 29, 2016 at 1:19 PM
I would also recommend fertility awareness based awareness cycles. There is a really good book called "A New Beginning" by the Kris-Ceely method, or check out the facebook group "It' a Girl's World", or the blog "The Fertile Soul" to learn more.
Wren March 29, 2016 at 12:40 AM
Thanks so much! This was very informative! I recently had a TA and it was one of the best decisions I've ever made.
Gina @ Life by Gina March 29, 2016 at 7:02 AM
Very informative and well written post :)
Dear Lilly March 29, 2016 at 9:18 AM
I know you were wondering about the risks as a woman in her mid 20's. I think you're actually just fine! My friend is about 25 and had a tubal ligation and got pregnant right away. I'm almost 28 and was pregnant right away.

I know a few people who have had this done and it's great to get the real facts and not the glossed over ones. Thanks for providing!

Great post! I had a TA done before my first child, because I definitely didn't think I wanted more children! After having my son and dealing with 3 pregnancies, I feel so much better about my decision. But as you said, the decision to get the TA is different for everyone!
Sara-Jayne Jones April 1, 2016 at 10:30 AM
This was a really informative post. I was actually thinking of getting a tubal ligation but I may be too young. Also I didn't have three miscarriages so I was wondering if I could be in the same situation as you where you are unable to have children naturally. I do know a few people who have had a TA which was successful for them. If it means that I cannot have children then I would be okay with it.
Lauren @ She Moved to Texas April 1, 2016 at 10:49 AM
What a wonderful, well balanced post. I think the main point is, whatever decision you make, know why you're making it.
My mom had 4 before having a TA. Although pregnancy is something that can't be denied (as she has been pregnant 2 or 3 more times after her TA) I think she did the right thing for herself. She loved parenting and was so sad after all of her lost miscarriages to let anyone else go through that.
I am a little young to have my tubes tied, but it is something my mom would have done. As I am in no rush to have kids, I think I'd rather do it for my own satisfaction than to be pregnant. I would like to try and get pregnant soon after, in this way I think it is the safest for me, but if not we would love more kids either way.

I assume you are given the point pressure at one place and the subcutaneous tissue pressure at another.  You find the permeability coefficient $P_t/P_p$ assuming the pressures are the same at the point and subcutaneous.  The rest is all pretty simple.  A rough approximation is to assume the permeability coefficient is independent of pressure- it is not- by the way, you have no way of knowing what happens in the tissue.  There is no simple way to calculate this without a fairly sophisticated knowledge of fluid mechanics.  You might get lucky because it might be possible to make a pretty good assumption (I have just found this example when I thought I knew everything).

Comment: I know it's wrong I just don't know how.  And I think it's also important for me to know the pressure because I don't know which pressure to use is subcutaneous or critical.

Comment: The solution manual doesn't explain what you're saying. I'm confused.

Comment: I assume it says you should take the pressure difference between the blood pressure and either the subcutaneous tissue pressure.  So the answer would be (100-20)*0.6/100=30 if the first condition was true, and (100-0)*0.6/100=40 if the second condition is true.

Hvac fan to blow on heat pump?
1. I have a two-story home (2200 sq foot). 2. It has two thermostats, one in the hallway (fellow's room) and the other in the family room. 3. Both have heat pumps and are controlled by the respective thermostats. 4. They're both located in the same area of the home, not in the attic. 5. I thought about running two different lines off the fan so that one line is connected to one system and one line is connected to the other system. So, depending whether the fan is on in one area of the home, so is the heat pump in the same area. Problem is that I would also like the heat pump that is not controlled by the thermostat (but by the thermostat in the hall) to stay on as long as the thermostat in the hall is. So, I was thinking this would be a problem because of my concern about the heats pump in the hallway being on longer than the one controlled by the thermostat in the hall. Does anyone see any flaw in this? Also, even if there is no flaw, is the fan powerful enough to both control the flow of air and run the heat pump? 4. The heat pumps have two wires (hot & neutral), the fan has two wires (hot & neutral). Is it this simple to run dual (or in my case, triple) lines?
Can a 30 amp fuse be protected by a breaker?
It is illegal to use a breaker to fuse a vehicle to the battery or fuse the battery to a vehicle. What is it legal to do is to use a breaker to fuse 240 volts/20 amps to the vehicle and a breaker to fuse the vehicle to the 12 volts/10 amp battery.
Do heat pumps make sense for a moderate climate?
The answer depends on your location (governed mostly by relative humidity) and your climate needs. Heat pumps are the most efficient way to go. A heat pump moves heat from one place to another. You could go with an ordinary air-conditioner for the summer (which is the reverse of what a heat pump does). Then, when it gets cold, have your ordinary cooling system switch over to be a heat pump (which uses about 40% less electricity). You could save on the average $600 a year in combined cooling costs. Now, as to the original question: does it make sense to replace your A/C unit with a Heat Pump and have your regular heat system act as AC in the summer? To do so, your furnace would have to act as a Heat Pump in the summer but, unless it's a new furnace, it won't because a standard/conventional furnace won't operate in reverse, unless it's a Geo Thermal system, which most people don't have. You're better off with just an A/C unit and a separate geothermal heat pump. To further explain, a typical electric A/C unit and an electric Heat Pump have identical electricity draw. To make it work in the "heat only" mode, you need a furnace capable of going from regular heat "mode" to gas or electric heating "mode". They're called "dual fuel". In fact, new home construction includes duel fuel furnaces (gas and electric) as standard. And, if you have a duel fuel A/C and heat pump, it will add about $1500+ to the cost. Most homes are built with only a 2-pipe A/C unit which contains the heat and A/C components integrated in one device. In addition, the HVAC system needs to be re-wired, so it will all work together. You should only consider a heat pump for heating. For cooling, AC units are just fine and cheaper and, if you need humidification, get a 2nd small AC unit since the first heat-pump will de-humidify the house and this is required in any room for humidification.
How is a pressure cooker/pressure cooker pressure regulated?
The pressure is regulated by an arm which moves back and forth with a piston.

1860-1900 (French Revolutions to WW1)
Revolutions across Europe
- The industrial revolution
- Reform movements
- Rise of nationalism and nationalism
New ways of thinking and doing things began to replace the old way of thinking and doing in the latter part of the eighteenth century.
Reform movements began to transform the lives of people in Europe.
Rise of nationalism and nationalism
Revolution: A political, economic or social event that causes a major change to an established government.
Rise of nationalism: A situation wherein some people in a country see their self more as part of a larger group, such as a nation, and less as part of a smaller group like a state, township, tribe, family etc.
Enlightenment philosophers like Voltaire and Montesquire. They questioned the Church and the way the kingdoms were governed.
Their ideas are still thought of being the roots of the French Revolution.
An economic, social and political reform movement.
Had the purpose of bringing the church and state together to be united under one system of belief and one system of laws.
Rousseau suggested a social contract between the state and the citzens as a way that would create the unity needed between state and citizen.
In the 19th century social and political reforms started to take shape.
1. The British parliament passed the Reform act of 1832 which gave power to the middle class.
2. The Chartist started with the idea of a written constitution for the United Kingdom.
3. The French took up arms in 1830 which led the revolution.
4. Germany was reunited as a country in 1871.
The idea was that the people should have the rights to rule.
That people should be ruled by the people.
The idea of a more equal society.
The French Revolution:
1. It was based around the Enlightenment ideas.
2. There were 100s of ideas and revolutions.
3. The ideas:
a. End feudalism
b. End monarchy
c. End of special privilege
d. End of the Roman Catholic Church and its influence.
e. Equality for everyone. Men and women should be treated equally.
End feudalism:
A system of running a country where lords owned all the land and the peasants worked the land. It ended in France with the revolution.
End monarchy:
The country was run by royalty and not democratically. It ended with the end of the Revolution.
End of special privilege:
It was the end of the idea that people could not be part of the governing system of the country because of their family.
Equality for everyone:
End of the Roman Catholic Church and it’s influence.
Men and women should be treated equally. Men did not have to ask the women's parent for permission to marry.
Government of the people by the people for the people.
New Ideas and Revolution:
1. There were more industrial power because of steam engines, railways and machinery.
2. Rise of the middle class. The lower class people could aspire to be middle class.
3. Social reforms in the country.
4. New laws:
a. The Factory Act of 1844:
Ended the 12 hour work day.
Safety in work places.
Penalty for unsafe work place.
b. The Poor Law of 1850:
State to provide help to poor people.
c. Childrens Act of 1874:
Government to act now for the children's welfare.
d. Marriage Act of 1878:
The Age of consent to be 18 years.
5. The rise of nationalism: People were more sensitive to the idea of being part of a nation than a smaller unit of the nation such as state, township, tribe of family etc.
Social Reforms:
The 1850s had massive social and cultural reforms.
Food: The sanitization of food and the discovery of a better way to process food led to more people able to join the better economy in the towns and cities.
Industrialisation: In the late 1800’s people in the towns and cities experienced the rapid growth and urbanisation. Industrialisation and nationalism. Nationalism started to grow in Europe.
Nationalism: Nationalism or national idea was the idea that the people in the state should be united.
Reaction- The new ideas that came out of Europe were considered very dangerous by the Church and the Royalty.
The Holy Alliance: This was a political and military alliance made up of the Russian Tsar and Austrian and Prussian kings. Their purpose was to defend the existing monarchies all over Europe against the ideas of Revolution.
Bismarck: The first chancellor of the German Empire. He united Germany.

Analysis essays are a wonderful way to display your thoughtful analysis which has been carefully and thoroughly worked out. So, how far can you go in writing an analysis? This article will help you to choose and write analysis essays. What, then, is an analysis essay and how do you write one? There are many types of essays and a good essay writer should have a firm grasp on the various essay forms he has written. An Analysis essay is a piece of writing in which the writer takes another piece of work such as a book, film, speech, advertisement, painting, poem, song, piece of sculpture, etc.
Then, the writer breaks down the work into parts, examining the techniques used by the writer to produce the finished work. He then analyzes the techniques in relation to the effect on the reader and tries to evaluate what the writer was trying to achieve.
What are the various types of analyses? Narrative An analytical essay on a narrative consists of analyzing the storyline of the work and trying to determine how the writer has manipulated the reader to achieve the desired result.
This essay will examine the effects of the techniques employed by the story as a whole. The author may wish to explain the difference between a narrative essay and a character analysis of a fictional character. Dramatic An analytical essay on a dramatic work could also be referred to as a critical essay. However, the author has to evaluate the work from the point of view of the dramatic critic rather than the literary critic.
The essays are often written about the play rather than the play character. How to start an analysis essay A proper start of the essay is of paramount significance if you want to make a strong impression on your readers. In your introduction paragraphs, you should outline the analysis that you have done of the work.
This will set out the tone as to how you will be approaching the topic. For example, if you have decided on doing a comparison between two pieces of work — say, a film and a song — by the same writer, it will be interesting to see how the two pieces of work compare with each other.
A good idea to kick off your analysis essay is to list down all the possible comparisons you can think of — say, the two characters, the plot, the message conveyed, the setting, etc. If this is too difficult to do, perhaps you should take a more logical approach. Compare the two works against each other. Do they deal with the same issues in the same way? Does the writer use the same techniques such as foreshadowing?
Do they make you feel the same way? The more points of commonality you establish at this level, the better it will be for you to proceed to your main analysis.
Doing some simple research on the authors of the two pieces of work can give you an idea of how they might approach their works. If their backgrounds are similar in some way, such as both having won a number of prestigious awards, it will serve as the base of your further research. Also, look for their published works and see how their writing styles differ.
Sometimes it is the background of the author that makes all the difference. Now, this is where the real fun begins. You will then begin to use all the basic analytical terms such as irony, symbol, allusion, etc, to explain the effect and the techniques that the writer used to produce the effect.
Analysis essays are a wonderful way to display your thoughtful analysis which has been carefully and thoroughly worked out. So, how far can you go in writing an analysis? This article will help you to choose and write analysis essays. What, then, is an analysis essay and how do you write one? There are many types of essays and a good essay writer should have a firm grasp on the various essay forms he has written.
The writer will then analyze the techniques in their entirety and not concentrate on one aspect such as irony. He will take a step back and look at the bigger picture.
Here, instead of analyzing just the technique in isolation, he will show how the technique was used — say, how the technique made the work seem more real or truthful or brought some humor to an otherwise serious situation. There are many ways to carry out a criticism. You may decide to use negative or positive analysis — either praise or take to task the work based on your point of view. One could also carry out more than one criticism — perhaps positive and negative criticism to see if there are any contradictions the way each criticism is worded or carried out.
There is no hard and fast rule for doing this, but it will also help a great deal if you can identify the target audience of your piece — a film for a child and a grown up will attract a very different audience, for example. Then, pick apart the techniques used by the writer and explain the effect on your readers. If you are using other criticisms, make sure that they follow your work rather than lead off. There are only so many techniques in a work of art but as you practice more and more with the different types of analysis, you will find that your vocabulary grows substantially.
Your readers will no longer find you hard to understand — but then, a good essay writer always aims to leave an impression on his readers. How to start an analysis essay A proper start of the essay is of paramount significance if you want to make a strong impression on your readers.

If this is too difficult to do, perhaps you should take a more logical approach. Compare the two works against each other. Do they deal with the same issues in the same way?

This paper proposes a novel neural network for explainable fake news detection based on raw reports from different media outlets. The proposed model consists of a hierarchical encoder for web text representation, and two cascaded selectors to select the most explainable sentences for verdicts. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art detection baselines and generates high-quality explanations from diverse evaluation perspectives. The paper also presents two explainable fake news datasets, which are publicly available.

1. Could the authors provide more detailed information on the implementation process of the proposed method?
2. Could the authors conduct more extensive evaluation and ablation studies to support the proposed method's performance?
3. Could the authors compare the proposed method with more widely-known baselines in the field?

\textcolor{black}{Our study shows that deep neural networks could be a good candidate to predict the quality of sentences in the raw content, but they cannot produce good quality explanations for their predictions. The best way to generate explanations could be to combine deep neural networks with rules extracted from human judgments}.

\section{Methodology}

This section discusses the details of the proposed model, which can be summarized as follows:

\begin{enumerate}
\item The representation of web texts from multiple media outlets is obtained by a bi-directional LSTM, which is a deep neural network architecture that processes both the sentence as forward and backward.
\item A high-quality sentence is extracted from web sources using a simple heuristic rule (i.e an indicator from each sentence):
\begin{equation}
r = \text{Explainable Fake News Detection} \times k\%
\end{equation}
where k is a percentage between 0 to 100 and indicates whether a certain sentence contains false information.
\item FINETUNE (i.e. the cascaded selectors) to improve the explainability of the obtained ranking list.
\end{enumerate}
Figure \ref{fig:overview} shows the overall architecture of the proposed HERMIONE model.

\subsubsection*{1. Representation of Web Text}
In this work, the media outlets of the web text are also the data sources, that is, the sources for training and testing. In order to effectively extract information, multiple news sources are selected instead of one single source. According to previous work \cite{xu2021}, the performance of neural networks in identifying false information is improved by using the same sources for training and testing, not using the same source for both steps. Therefore, in the following sections, we will use 12 news sources as the data sources.

\begin{figure}[t]
\centering
\includegraphics[height=4.8cm]{1.png}
\caption{The proposed HERMIONE model. }
\label{fig:overview}
\end{figure}

The neural network contains a Bi-LSTM Layer as shown in Figure \ref{fig:overview}. We believe that the sentence and its context are not independent. Therefore, to better solve the problem of fake news detection, we used the Bi-LSTM neural network to extract sentences and text from different perspectives.

\subsubsection*{2. High Quality Sentence Selection \& FINETUNE}
High-quality sentences are selected by simply dividing the neural representation of a text into several sentences, and then ranking the sentences based on the percentage of ``fake news'' predicted by the neural network, i.e., a linear weighted average of the predicted ``false news'' for its representation.

The first-level classification ranking model selects the five sentences with the highest predicted probability within the first 600 words of the article. Therefore, the sentence with the highest predicted probability is the ``gold standard" sentence, and the sentence with the highest predicted probability is the ``fake news" sentence. As the predicted sentence increases, the percentage of fake news is reduced. Thus, in the ``explainable" selection process, the ``fake news" sentence is identified as the ``true sentence" and the ``true sentence" predicted by the neural network is identified as the ``false sentence" as shown in Figures \ref{fig:overview} and \ref{fig:example}.

After extracting a group of sentences that are likely to contain false news, the second-level selector, FINETUNE, selects these sentences to enhance the quality of the explanations. The goal of fine-tuning is to find the ranking of sentences in the final explanations to improve the level of comprehensiveness of the sentence, so that the explanation is easier to comprehend and understand for users.

More specifically, in each of the selected five sentences, we use the original neural network model or a pre-trained model for each media outlet to select the next sentence in the sentence sequence. Here, we use the final predicted sentence of the media outlet as a ranking factor for the next sentence. The model is a fine-tuned version of the model used for explanation. Since the selected five sentences are highly likely to contain false information, the next sentence in the ranking can be regarded as containing highly relevant information. We find the next sentence using the neural network model and then rank the sentences again according to their prediction likelihood and keep the top five sentences to generate an explanation, with the top sentence being the most truthful and the last sentence being the least truthful as shown in Figures \ref{fig:overview} and \ref{fig:example}.

\begin{figure*}[t]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\linewidth]{2.png}
\caption{Example of explanation from TheNewYorkTimes. This explanation involves the first 3 sentences of the article, which were selected from the article. The final sentence (which is related to the story title) is classified as unreliable (74) and is the highest unreliable rating in the ranking.}
\label{fig:example}
\end{figure*}

\subsection{Evaluation Metrics}

In order to further verify the high quality of the sentence ranking selected by FINETUNE and FINETUNE itself for generating satisfactory explanations, we have evaluated HERMIONE in different scenarios using the following metrics \cite{mazzoni2010}:

\begin{itemize}
\item Accuracy is a very simple form of accuracy of a model, by determining the percentage of incorrect results among the predicted results. From the standpoint of interpretation, accuracy is not the most representative, but is used because of its simplicity.
\item Clarity of the selected sentences is a measure of whether the selected sentences contain misleading information. Based on this measure, we found FINETUNE to improve sentence clarity in this sentence selection problem.
\item The explanations themselves are also evaluated regarding their quality. The explanation quality score (or EQS) metric can be used to measure this property, since the selected sentences are extracted from the original sentences. In order to measure the quality of an explanation, the explanation is usually judged against a set of pre-defined rules.
\end{itemize}

Therefore, Table \ref{tab:evaluation} reflects the summary of the evaluation results of HERMIONE using these three metrics.

\section{Results and Analysis}

Table \ref{tab:evaluation} shows the evaluation results of HERMIONE. The overall score (69.12\%), the clarity score (75.5\%). The overall score represents the percentage of fake news. The clarity score represents the percentage of sentences with a high clarity score. instruction:
How can you improve your paper writing in academic style by using effective transitions and signposts? What are the functions and types of transitions and signposts in academic writing? How can you use them to connect your ideas and guide your reader? An example of a paragraph that lacks transitions and signposts is:

The main cause of global warming is the greenhouse effect. Greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface. Carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas. It is produced by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas. The more fossil fuels we burn, the more carbon dioxide we emit.
You need to polish the paragraph.

The main cause of global warming is the greenhouse effect. Greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface. Carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas. It is produced by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas. The more fossil fuels we burn, the more carbon dioxide we emit.

428100, 2018 and A0OI204, Page 1 of 10 1
GLOBAL WARMING IS PROBABLY THE MOST WIDESPREAD Causes of Global WarmingGreenhouse effectThe greenhouse effect is one of the main causes of global warming. It occurs when gases such as carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and water vapour trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface.(Learn more at: https://www.bbc.co.uk/bitesize/guides/z4g2p9q/revision/1)
The most important greenhouse gas is carbon dioxide. It is a natural part of the environment and is produced by all plants and animals. When we burn fossil fuels such as coal and natural gas, we also release large amounts of carbon dioxide. The more fossil fuels we burn, the more carbon dioxide we emit.Global warming is a global phenomenonWe all share the Earth. Because of this, the effects of global warming are felt all over the world, affecting every population. In the last 100 years, the average global temperature has increased by 0.85°C. (That’s just over 1.5°F.) This is happening more and more each year.What are the effects of global warming?The effects of global warming include extreme weather such as floods, storms, and heatwaves. Longer heatwaves will cause extreme heat stress and impact on crops. Floods can lead to shortages of food, clean water and medicine. (Learn more at: https://www.bbc.co.uk/bitesize/topics/zcnd2hv/articles/zy4rwv4)
We use two broad groups of signs and transitions in academic English:

Signposts are words, phrases or sentences that tell your reader what is coming next.

Transitions are words or phrases that help you connect ideas.
An example of signposts is in the example below:

1) Greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface. 2) Carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas. 3) Carbon dioxide is produced by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas. 4) The more fossil fuels we burn, the more carbon dioxide we emit.

Read the above paragraph, and you will see that there are many signposts in the paragraph. What are they?

First, we give information about greenhouse gases, then we say that CO2 is one of the most important greenhouse gases, then we state that it is produced from burning fossil fuels. Lastly, we mention that CO2 is mainly produced due to burning fossil fuels.

Do you see this pattern in the example below?

The main cause of global warming is the greenhouse effect.
When gases such as carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and water vapour trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface, it is called greenhouse effect.
When we burn fossil fuels such as coal and natural gas, we also release large amounts of carbon dioxide, so this is one of the most important causes of global warming.
Global warming is a global phenomenon, and we all share the Earth. Because of this, the effects of global warming are felt all over the world, affecting every population.
In the last 100 years, the average global temperature has increased by 0.85oC.
(That’s just over 1.5ºF.) This is happening more and more each year.
The effects of global warming include extreme weather such as floods, storms, and heatwaves. (Read more) Longer heatwaves will cause extreme heat stress and impact on crops. Floods can lead to shortages of food, clean water and medicine.

Do you understand what I mean?
You may wonder: is it possible to write an effective academic style without using transition words? The answer is yes, but it will be harder for you to write because your paragraphs will not flow smoothly and your paragraphs will be short and not well structured.
Therefore, in general, you should use all these transitions and signposts as much as possible.

Before we start, here are some important things to know:I will use a lot of examples to show you the effect of using transitions and signposts in your paragraphs.
I will also show you how to use or avoid too much connective or transitional words, but I encourage you to use them in a reasonable amount.
Some transitions that you shouldn’t use include “however, furthermore, indeed, on the other hand, in addition, notably, in fact, namely, that being said, therefore”.
I will also teach you that when you are writing, you should first make an outline and write the whole draft then go back and perfect your draft.

Let’s begin!

### The Difference of Transitions and Signposts

Transitions and signposts can be defined as the same, but they are used differently. First, I will explain the difference between the function of signposts and transitions, and what words I am looking for to help you understand better.

As you know, signs and transitions are words, phrases or sentences that give information. Sign posts are used to direct your reader as to what is coming next. On the other hand, we have transitions that show the relation of ideas between sentences, paragraphs and essays.

Transitions are usually used to present information, but when you use transitions to join sentences with related information, it is called a signpost. There are some words that you may want to use, but you shouldn’t use them as often: “however, furthermore, indeed, on the other hand, in addition, notably, in fact, namely, that being said, therefore“. These can be used occasionally, not frequently.

Let us now look at how to use transitions and signposts to connect your paragraphs.

### Connecting Paragraphs

When you are writing an essay, paragraphs are the building blocks of the essay. The most common type of paragraph is the general structure or description, which contains the topic, supporting point, evidence and example. There are other types of paragraphs you may see, but this is the most common structure. The paragraphs need to be connected somehow. To connect your paragraphs, I will talk about two types of transitional words or expressions: connectives (used for a reason) and transitional words (used mostly without considering).

I often see the most commonly used connective is **also** (or the adverb version of it), also known as the co-ordinator. It is usually used for two ideas or two events happening at the same time.
This is used when you want to show more information about why something happened, but most students overuse it as much as possible, which makes their essays sound overloaded. Try to use them at the right place according to your topic. In addition to that, you should also avoid using transitions such as **however, furthermore, indeed, on the other hand, but** unless you want to show that **you disagree and give a reason** (that is when you start a paragraph with “however and show a difference in your topic or evidence). Try to avoid using them as much as possible.

Instead of using a connective (co-ordinator), use other words to connect some ideas, such as the following words:

- Contrary to…
- Other than that…
- On the contrary to…
- Not only…
- But also…
- Besides…
- Besides that…
- In contrast…
- Moreover…
- Furthermore…
- Additionally/Alternatively…
- Even more…
- At the same time…
- Likewise…
- Besides…
- On top of that…

**You can use both connectives (co-ordinator) and signposts to** connect** your paragraphs or present arguments**, for example. For example, if your paragraphs have too many transitions, maybe you can use co-ordinators and transitions at the end of each paragraph to avoid too many transitions, just follow your needs**.

**You can use both connectives (co-ordinator) and signposts to** connect your paragraphs**, for example. For example, if your paragraphs have too many transitions, maybe you can use c**o-ordinators and transitions at the end of each paragraph to avoid too many transitions**.

Just for a simple example, one common type of paragraph structure is as follows.

#### A General Paragraph Structure:

A general paragraph structure consists of a theme or topic sentence, detail sentences (subtopics) and supporting evidence such as examples, and details with reasons.

An example of the above sentence might be:

The 1957 film, “The Graduate”, is an example of a classic romantic comedy. The main character is the graduate who falls in love with an older woman and is pursued by her daughter and has many different emotions in the movie. This movie is a classic, romantic comedy film that most people remember well. (Read more)

As shown, you see I used some transitions (but, first, because, moreover) and some connectors (therefore, so, though).

What is the advantage of using transitions and connectors?

There are many advantages of using transitions and connectors in paragraphs, such as:

- It makes your paragraphs flow smoothly.
- Your paragraphs will be more coherent.
- Your paragraphs will be more natural.

#### Connectors and Transitions Between Paragraphs

Sometimes, we need to give the idea of continuation or a change of topic in the paragraph. One thing we can do is to use co-ordinators to connect our paragraphs together. However, this is not the ideal case. Here is the thing. If you need to continue your paragraph without changing the topic, you may use a **transition to show that the new paragraph continues the same information.

For example, **but** is a common transitional word used to show the similar topic or same information.

Another example may be: **In addition,**

**You can also continue your paragraph without changing the topic but connecting it by using a connective** between co-ordinators or between sentences. For example, **yet** can be used to emphasize the contrast between the new paragraph and the old one. Sometimes you do not need to give a transition between two paragraphs unless you are writing in academic style.

**You can also connect your paragraphs without connecting them with a** transition or connective, **but this is not a good style. Here are some things to remember.** Instead of using a transition, you can use connectives such as “because“; “and”; “so “; “hence”; “therefore“; “moreover“.

**You can instead use connectives such as “because“; “and”; “so “; “hence”; moreover “therefore“

instead of using transitions**.

Here is an example of using connectives without transitions.

**1) Because** you are writing an essay, you will need to have a title and a subtitle.

**2) And**, you will have to provide some information about the title of your essay and the subtitle of your essay.

**3) In addition,** when you are writing an essay, you will need to do some research, or you will need to give the reasons why you believe something is right or wrong.

**4) Finally**, you will need to write an introduction and conclusion.

Instead of using a transition, we can simply use connectives.

#### Using Transitions and Connectives

**The above example you just read is a basic example**. In addition to co-ordinating your paragraphs that I mentioned before in the “Connecting Paragraphs section”.

You can use more complex ways to connect your paragraphs, such as writing in the first person, using pronouns, and using specific words such as **therefore, thus, consequently, furthermore, hence, however, nevertheless, besides, otherwise, on the other hand, however.**

**1) However** can be used in a positive sentence and in a negative sentence. **2) In the positive, however,** it means the opposite and in the negative it means though.

**3) Furthermore,** these connectors or words are not limited to only one type of word or connective. Instead of using the co-ordinator **also,** you can use the transitional word **furthermore**.

**4) Moreover,** I can use any type of words or transitional words such as **nevertheless,** **in contrast, at the same time,** **besides the fact that,** for example, etc.

**In conclusion,** use the transitional words (transition words) and connectives not only for the purpose of changing topic but also to make your writing sound better.

Try to use specific words to connect your paragraphs or topic ideas and if you are still not satisfied, ask your teacher what words you should use when you are going to present your arguments.

As you can see, I do not usually use transitional words or transitional words such as “however“, “moreover“, “nevertheless“, etc as much as possible (at the right time) unless I want to introduce new ideas in a paragraph.

I usually try to use **more specific words to connect the topics and paragraphs.** In the below example, I used the words (transition words): “because of“, “therefore“, “moreover“, “hence“, “consequently“.

1) We will do this because…

2) Therefore, we will also…

3) Moreover, we will also…

4) In addition, we will also…

5) More than, we will also…

6) Because, we will also…

7) Hence, we will also…

8) Consequently, we will also…

Trying to use more specific words to connect ideas and paragraphs.

We will do this because we will help develop and improve students’ speaking, listening skills and confidence.

Therefore, we will also teach the correct accent and pronunciation, and in addition we will also teach other related skills.

Moreover, we will also teach the grammar rules in a clear way so students learn quickly.

You can also use more specific words with a reason that will support your ideas.

Simply add the reason to the end of a sentence or paragraph, just like the above examples:

We will do this because we will help develop and improve students’ speaking, listening skills and confidence.

Therefore, we will also teach the correct accent and pronunciation, and in addition, we will also teach other related skills such as speaking style, speech fluency, and speech confidence.

### Using Connectors Signposts Effectively

I have showed what type of transitions and signposts you should use and how to use them correctly. Let’s now focus on some other areas about how to write a good paragraph.

Let us look at how to write a good topic sentence.

1) Make sure your topic sentence contains a topic and two supporting topic ideas. For example:

2) Support your reasons by writing specific points with details or examples in each sentence. Remember: details are not just sentences, or something that gives information. It should be an image to show you are giving information.

3) You should use transitions or connectives to make them flow smoothly and make it look like a paragraph by using words such as “first“, “moreover“, “finally“, etc.

4) Finally, you should use co-ordinators or transitions between paragraphs. Transitions should be used to connect paragraphs together when you are giving your ideas and presenting arguments.

I hope the information above has been helpful for you and it is a good outline for writing your paragraphs, and remember to practice a lot because practice will make you better at writing. Try writing paragraphs by yourself and ask your teacher/teaching assistant to look over them. You can also take your writing down and try to make it flow.

### Reasons about Writing Signposts and Transitions

You have reached the last sections of this presentation. Writing signposts and transitions is very important. First of all, as I mentioned earlier, you should have a general structure or outline so that everything is organized.

Secondly, you should use connectives such as **and** and **because** to make it connect and flow smoothly. This gives the readers a good impression of your writing.

Thirdly, make sure that you use the correct connectives for a paragraph or topic. Do not use more than three co-ordinators in a sentence. I suggest you use only two connective words such as **and,** and **because,** after your topic. Then after that, add some co-ordinators (three or more).

This course covers the C++ programming language in depth. It gives students the opportunity to develop proficiency in object-oriented programming techniques. The course covers all required topics in the most recent Oracle Certified Professional Java Programmer exam as well as many that are good preparation for the Advanced Java Developer and the Professional Java Architect exams. Through the use of real-world applications, students have the opportunity to develop, debug, test, and document the applications that they submit as their projects for the course. The emphasis is on developing objectoriented solutions. However, due to the difficulty of object-oriented programming, an examination and comparison of procedural, object-oriented, and generic approaches is also undertaken. Students will learn how to read and write C++ source code, use the standard data structures in C++, and to create and use class library object-oriented constructs such as classes, objects, interfaces, and frameworks.
Assignments: 15% Practical assessments: 35% Final examination: 50%
• Introduction to programming and problem solving with C++. • Introduction to computer system organisation, design, and programming techniques. • C++ Object-Oriented Programming. • Arrays. • Functions. • Control flow and data structures. • Introduction to Exceptions. • Standard C++ data structures. • Object-oriented design. • Structure of an object. • Object-Oriented Programming. • Managing State. • Polymorphism. • An Object's Behaviour • Encapsulation. • Inheritance. • Access Control. • Overloading. • Static Membership. • Generic Programming. Teaching methods: Lectures and Tutorials. Assessment: Continuous Assessment (24%); Final Examination (76%). Attendance Requirements: 75% Pre-Requisites/Exclusions: Assessment/Result Criteria: A minimum of 40% requires for assessment.

instruction: You can write C# code. Given an unsorted array of integers, sort it using quicksort algorithm. For example, if the array is [10, 80, 30, 90, 40, 50, 70], then after sorting it using quicksort, it should be [10, 30, 40, 50, 70, 80, 90]. Quicksort is a divide-and-conquer algorithm that works by choosing a pivot element from the array and partitioning the array into two subarrays such that all elements less than or equal to the pivot are in the left subarray and all elements greater than the pivot are in the right subarray. Then it recursively sorts the left and right subarrays until the array is sorted.

instruction: Given two strings, find the longest common subsequence between them. A subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, “ace” and “ae” are subsequences of “abcde” but “aec” and “cba” are not. The longest common subsequence (LCS) between two strings is the longest subsequence that is common to both strings. For example, if the two strings are “ABCDGH” and “AEDFHR”, then the LCS is “ADH” with length 3. Please use Java to solve the above question.
